text: Not sure if any of you care about SEO — but I’m looking at this page: <https://www.HubSpot.com/products/marketing/blog>
the h1 is blogging
Do any of you think  the paragraph content below the h1 would be a better h1?
Not sure if I’m looking for an expert opinion --
i can attest to loval and timber both are awesome and super easy to use.
local it docker for idiots
is*

My setup - 
hop on any computer or tablet in the world that I want

Install/Open Google chrome.

autologin to <http://codeanywhere.com|codeanywhere.com>
(IDE, dev boxes(all have npm, sass already set up etc.), FTP client, git client, SSH terminal, etc.)
autologin to <http://saucelabs.com|saucelabs.com>
(live browser testing suite)
autologin to HubSpot account
autologin to installed Slack client or Web client

Relax and get to work.

*I'm device agnostic*
only 2 apps I am not yet ready to replace(there are web alternatives, but they don't yet meet the level of standards I need for work) - Photoshop and Illustrator.

The day a suitable photoshop or illustrator alternative for the web can reliably edit photoshop, and illustrator files, with almost all of the same functionality and quality. I will happily go completely web based.

I think yes the paragraph below it is better. Little wordy for an h1 but competing on SEO for the word "blogging" alone is going to mean stiff competition. The paragraph text better summarizes what the rest of the pages content is about - providing more meaning that Google can extract to better point users to the page.

I won't claim to be an SEO guru though. I don't follow the SEO trends and whatnot as well as I should.
i feel like a good H1 would be "A fully integrated blogging platform " then just remove that from the H2 and leave it be "Power your content marketing into overdrive"
wow
love it

So not sure on peoples musical interests but a new radio station emerged here in the Chicago area and its all 90's R&B, def worth a listen if that was your Jam back in the day: <https://tunein.com/radio/1043-Jams-s29910/>
Actually, raises a good question, what's everyone's music of choice when coding?
Kanye West, Odesza, EDM/Dubstep/Trap/Ambient or similar types

I have a few different spotify playlists that server their purpose on different coding items. like I have one specific playlist when I get into a tough spot, late at night and I need to power through.
my office mate listens to 80s a lot, so that works also because I drown out most of the lyrics — very hard to listen to new music
because then I have to listen
We used to have this setup in the office: <https://ufo.ai/amp/>
it was pretty awesome to see people's choices... until justin beiber and other terrible music came on lol
then i judged hard

haha that's pretty awesome.
Currently we have a google home mini set up in our office with a chromecast audio hooked up to some other speakers, we take turns telling the little white hockey puck to play 80's music 90's music old techno/edm  rock, movie soundtracks  and now until we rip our ears off or throw the google home across the office - Christmas Music
I also have a few different lists depending on the work to be done.
I’m going to say there is nothing wrong with pop music lol
JUDGE HARD IF YOU FEEL
lol
lol, i wont deny that i have been guilty of listening to pop music myself
#LookAtWhatYouMadeMeDo
if its got a good beat, i listen
<-closet t swift fan myself
